quest.name: Glory to the Khagan
journal: Hien has what can be best described as a “shite-eating grin.”
objectives: Speak with the diligent Mol warrior.
Strike a /victorypose at the mark of Mol Iloh.

dialogue.name: LYSE
dialogue.text: Go on! They're waiting for you, I'm sure!

dialogue.name: GOSETSU
dialogue.text: The others have returned as well, it would seem.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: We won...we actually won! I mean, you did. If it were not for you...

dialogue.name: DORBEI
dialogue.text: I...I took a wound. But it will heal with time and care. The children are gathering herbs for a poultice.

dialogue.name: DORBEI
dialogue.text: Had the Naadam lasted much longer, I may not have survived. Thank you.

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: I saw you fight, Forename! You were incredible!

dialogue.name: MOLB02514
dialogue.text: My arms, my legs, everything is tired and sore. I feel as though I could sleep for a day...

dialogue.name: MOLC02514
dialogue.text: Where did you learn such feats? Is everyone in the West as strong as you? Can you teach me!?

dialogue.name: MOLD02514
dialogue.text: Stop fidgeting and let me set the bone! You're only making it worse for yourself!

dialogue.name: MOLE02514
dialogue.text: <pant> <pant> I know, I know! Just...just give me a moment!

dialogue.name: HIEN
dialogue.text: Ah, but it would be rude of me to monopolize your attention. Doubtless there are others who would speak with you.

dialogue.name: HIEN
dialogue.text: Let us go and greet Temulun Khatun.

dialogue.name: LYSE
dialogue.text: I hope everyone is all right...or alive, at least.

dialogue.name: HIEN
dialogue.text: Temulun Khatun! We are returned, and victorious!

dialogue.name: GOSETSU
dialogue.text: Ah...mayhap you should speak with the khatun instead of me. That is why we are here, is it not?

dialogue.name: TEMULUN
dialogue.text: Welcome, warriors of the Steppe. It is an honor to receive you once more.

dialogue.name: TEMULUN
dialogue.text: We observed the battle from a distance, and marked the moment of your triumph. In that instant, I wept tears of joy.

dialogue.name: TEMULUN
dialogue.text: Not only did you bring us victory in the Naadam, but you ensured that every one of my kinsmen returned with their lives.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: Some were more gravely wounded than others, but none were lost to us. We could not have asked for anything more.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: If it is not too much of an imposition, would you be willing to go and speak with them? A simple gesture for those with whom you shared the battlefield.

dialogue.name: LYSE
dialogue.text: You really shouldn't... I mean, I'm glad you're all right, but we had our own reasons for fighting, and it feels wrong to be thanked for that...

dialogue.name: HIEN
dialogue.text: Hahaha! The pleasure and the pain that can only come in the wake of a battle. I know it well.

dialogue.name: GOSETSU
dialogue.text: How long it has been since last I saw young men and women celebrating a hard-fought victory... Let us pray we enjoy a similar sign in Yanxia soon.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: Please, it would mean a great deal to the others if you were to go and speak with them again.

dialogue.name: TEMULUN
dialogue.text: For the Mol to triumph in the Naadam with the aid of outsiders. The Steppe will not soon forget this day.

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: Some part of me still struggles to believe it, but we won! We defeated the Oronir and the Dotharl and won!

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: When they appeared before us I was filled with such fear as I had never known. But then I saw you charge with Cirina and the others, and before I knew it, I was running and shouting...

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: I will carry the memory of that moment with me always. As well as the moment when you became one with the ovoo and were declared khagan!

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: The victorypose you struck was a sight to behold! I say, would you be willing to show us again?

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: It is a silly thing to ask, I know, but I must! Please, will you not show us again your grand victorypose?

dialogue.name: MOLC02514
dialogue.text: Aye, that's the stuff of legends! That's the khagan in all herhis splendor!

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: Praise be to the khagan, and to the gods for guiding herhim to us!

dialogue.name: MOLD02514
dialogue.text: Glory to the khagan and herhis comrades! Forever and forever! A hundred years! The khagan!

dialogue.name: LYSE
dialogue.text: I think they love you, Forename! They really, really love you!

dialogue.name: HIEN
dialogue.text: It is good that they can delight in such simple things as the dramatic posings of a comrade.

dialogue.name: GOSETSU
dialogue.text: Like the child and the father, the student and the master, all men need an ideal for which to strive.

dialogue.name: MOLA02514
dialogue.text: How impressive! I shall have to practice with my own weapons until I can do the same!

dialogue.name: MOLB02514
dialogue.text: I could hear the others cheering. What did I miss? Is there to be a feast or some other celebration?

dialogue.name: MOLC02514
dialogue.text: How I envy you, khagan! You could court the manwoman of your choice!

dialogue.name: MOLD02514
dialogue.text: Have a care that it heals properly. There is much work to be done, and you will be needed.

dialogue.name: MOLE02514
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, I know...even in victory we must look to the future.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: Ah, Forename! I am told you gave the young warriors a fine show!

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: Grandmother and I have been discussing how we might best express our gratitude to you. Mere words did not seem sufficient.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: This is a morin khuur─a traditional instrument of our people.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: The feats of our greatest heroes, like Bardam and Chakha, are preserved in song. Yours too will live on for years to come.

dialogue.name: CIRINA
dialogue.text: Perhaps one day you might learn how to play it! But, even if not, you may look on the morin khuur and remember this time, this place. As we will when we hearken to the music.
